The adsorbent binding capacity for Factor VIII increases significantly with a decrease in volume mean particle diameter. The experiment illustrates the superior performance of adsorbents having a volume mean particle diameter below 150 µm.
Isolation of human plasma proteins from human plasma using adsorbents coupled with different aromatic or hetero-aromatic ligands comprising acidic groups
description.heading: Adsorbents
description.p: The adsorbents were all based on agarose with tungsten carbide particles incorporated, the density of the conglomerate particles was 2.9 g/ml and the particle diameter was in the range of 40-120 µm with a volume mean particle diameter of 70 µm. The adsorbents were cross-linked and activated with epichlorohydrin and coupled with the following different ligands: 2-mercaptonicotinic acid, 2-mercapto-benzoic acid, 3,4-diamino-benzoic acid, 2,4-dihydroxy-benzoic acid, 3,5-dihydroxy-benzoic acid, 2-(4-aminophenylthio)acetic acid, 2-mercapto-benzimidazole sulphonic acid, N-benzoyl-cysteine.
The ligand concentration on all the individual adsorbents was determined by acid-base titration to be in the range of 25 - 40 micromoles per ml sedimented adsorbent.
The following experiment was performed for each adsorbent:
description.heading: Pre-treatment of the protein solution
description.p: The protein solution, human plasma, was diluted with demineralised water in a ratio of one volume of plasma to 2 volumes of water and pH was adjusted to pH 5.0 with 1 M hydrochloric acid. The conductivity was hereafter 5,25 mS/cm2
description.heading: Process parameters:
description.p: The experiment was performed in a FastLine® 10 expanded bed column (0=1 cm) product number 7010-0000, UpFront Chromatography A/S.

The column was loaded with adsorbent to reach a settled bed height (HO) of 50 cm (corresponding to approx 40 ml settled adsorbent) and washed and equilibrated at 20-25 °C with the following buffers in successive order 1) 1 M NaOH, 2) 40 mM citric acid buffer pH 4.5 3) 40 mM citric acid buffer pH 5.0.
The experiment was performed with a linear flow rate of 600 cm/hr in all steps and the outlet from the column was connected to an UV monitor and recorder.
description.heading: Sample:
description.p: 30 ml sample (corresponding to 10 ml undiluted plasma) was loaded onto the column.
description.heading: Collection of Fractions:
description.p: Following loading of the protein solution, non-bound and weakly bound material was washed out of the column with 10 mM sodium citrate pH 5.0. The run-through and washing fraction, RT, (unbound fraction) was collected as one fraction according to the UV monitoring of the column effluent.

Subsequently the bound proteins were eluted in three sequential steps.
Eluate 1 - first elution step was performed with sodium caprylate 5 mg/ml, pH 6.0
Eluate 2 - second elution step was performed with 0.3 M sodium citrate pH 7.4.
Eluate 3 - third elution step was performed with 20 mM sodium citrate + 0.1 M sodium chloride pH 7.4
In between first and second elution step the column was washed with 1 column volume of 1 M sodium citrate pH 7.4

Quantification of human plasma proteins in Run-through/washing fraction and elution 1, 2, and 3: Single Radial Immunodiffusion (SRI) was performed in order to demonstrate the components in each fraction from the column as described in Scand. J. Immunol. Vol. 17, Suppl. 10, 41-56, 1983.

The SRI was performed with the following antibodies, all from Dako Cytomation, Denmark:
AntibodyCode no.µl sample/wellµl per cm2
Rabbit anti human AlbuminA 00015 µl0.30 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human IgGA 04245 µl0.30 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human Alpha-1-PIA 00125 µl0.60 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human FibrinogenA 00805 µl0.40 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human OrosomucoidA 00115 µl0.80 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human TransferrinA 00615 µl0.30 µl per cm2

A standard curve was established with the protein solution (100 % reference) loaded onto the column in the concentration of 100 %, 80 %, 60%, 40 % and 20 %. Each of the four fractions was determined relative to this standard curve and the relative yield of the specific protein in each fraction was determined. If the yield of a specific protein in a specific fraction relative to the amount of protein added to the column is above 5 % the protein is defined to distribute into said fraction.
description.heading: Results

row.entry: Distribution of selected proteins as a function of ligand structure
RT= Run through and first wash, E1= Eluate 1, E2= Eluate 2, E3= Eluate 3

description.p: Threshold: At least 5 % of the specific protein applied to the column must be present in the fraction

The table illustrates that for the ligand 2-mercapto-nicotinic acid, alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein are only present, to a degree of more than 5 % of the total, in the combined run-through and washing fraction, while Albumin is only present in the first eluate, E1, i.e. there is no significant amount of albumin present in any of the other fractions, IgG and transferrin are only present in the second eluate and fibrinogen is only present in the third eluate. Thus generally it can be noted that there is very little cross-contamination of the individual proteins between the individual protein fractions obtained in the experiment. The experiment further illustrates that a broad range of aromatic or hetero-aromatic ligands comprising an acidic group may be used for the fractionation of human plasma or serum proteins according to the invention.
Isolation of human alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor (alpha-1-PI) from non-bound fraction of example 5 at low ionic strength using adsorbent with a diamino-nonane ligand.
description.heading: Adsorbent
description.p: The adsorbent was based on 4 % agarose with tungsten carbide particles incorporated. The conglomerate beads had a density of approximately 3.8 g/ml and a particle size in the range of 40-100 µm with a volume mean particle size of 60 µm. The adsorbent was cross-linked and activated with epichlorohydrin and coupled with diamino-nonane. The ligand concentration was approx. 25 µmoles per ml sedimented adsorbent.
description.heading: Protein solution
description.p: The starting material for this experiment was Protein fraction 1 (the non-bound material) obtained from isolation of human plasma proteins using expanded bed adsorption as described in example 5. The pH in the protein fraction was carefully adjusted to pH 8.2 with 1 M sodium hydroxide and the conductivity was adjusted to 3.0 mS/cm2 by the addition of demineralised water.
description.heading: Process parameters
description.p: The experiment was performed as an expanded bed adsorption.
The experiment was performed in a FastLine® 10 expanded bed column (Ø=1 cm) product number 7010-0000, UpFront Chromatography A/S.

The column was loaded with adsorbent to reach a settled bed height (H0) of 20 cm (corresponding to 16 ml adsorbent) and washed and equilibrated at 20-25 °C with the following buffers in successive order 1) 1 M NaOH, 2) 0.2 M HCl 3) 50 % ethanol in water 4) 10 mM Tris/HCI pH 8.2
The experiment was performed with a linear flow rate of 900 cm/hr in ail steps and the outlet from the column was connected to an UV monitor and recorder.
description.heading: Sample
description.p: 700 ml of the protein fraction adjusted to pH 8.2 and a conductivity of 3.0 mS/cm was loaded onto the column and the run-through fractions (non-bound material). After loading of the protein fraction, the column was washed with 10 mM Tris/HCI pH 8.2. The run-through and the washing fraction were collected as one combined fraction (using the UV-monitor to follow the wash out of un-bound material). Following loading and washing the bound alpha-1-PI was released and eluted with 15 mM potassium sodium citrate pH 6.0 and collected as Eluate 1. When all alpha-1-PI was eluted, as monitored on the UV-monitor, a second elution buffer, 15 mM sodium citrate +500 mM sodium chloride pH 5.2 was then applied to release alpha-1-acid-glycoprotein as Eluate 2. Eluate 2 was collected according to the peak obtained on the UV-recorder.
description.heading: Quantification of human alpha-1-PI from the column
description.p: Single Radial Immunodiffusion (SRI) was performed in order to quantify the relative concentration of alpha-1-PI and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (orosomucoid) in the fractions from the column as described in Scand. J. Immunol. Vol. 17, Suppl. 10, 41-56, 1983.
The SRI was performed with Rabbit anti-human API Cat. No.: A0012 (0.6 µl per cm2) and Rabbit anti human Orosomucoid Cat. No. A 00110 (0.8 µl per cm2) from DakoCytomation, Denmark,

A standard curve was performed for each of the two proteins applied with the protein fraction as the 100 % reference loaded onto the column in the concentration of 100 %, 80 %, 60%, 40 % and 20 %. The alpha-1-PI and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein concentration in each of the fractions was determined against the standard curve and the relative yield in that fraction was calculated from the volume of the fraction relative to the volume and concentration of alpha-1-PI in the applied protein fraction.
Purity of eluate and demonstration of elastase binding activity.
description.heading: SDS-PAGE
description.p: For SDS-PAGE, Invitrogen SDS-Page 4-20 % Tris-Glycine gel (cat no. EC6025) was used.
description.heading: Elastase binding
description.p: Demonstration of the elastase binding activity of the alpha-1-PI in the protein fraction was performed by analysing the raw material with SDS-PAGE before and after incubation with elastase (Sigma code no E0127): The protein fraction was adjusted to pH 7 with 0.2 M NaOH and 500 µl of the protein fraction was added 6.5 µl elastase 2.5mg/ml and incubated for 30 min. at 30° C. Sample preparation: 25 µl sample and 25 µi sample buffer tris-glycine Invitrogen (cat no. LC2676) was mixed and boiled for 5 minutes in a water bath. The running buffer 0.024 M tris (Sigma T1378), 0.19 M glycine (Merck 5001901000), 0.1 % SDS (sodium dodecyl sulphate, JT Baker 2811) pH 8.6 was added. 20µl sample was applied in each analysis slot and the power was adjusted to give a current of 40 mA. When the blue line from the sample buffer reached one cm from the bottom of the gel the power was turned off and the gel was stained overnight in Invitrogen Colloidal Blue Staining Kit (cat. no. LC 6025) on a shaking table. The next day the gel was transferred into water and de-stained in water for 2 hours.
description.heading: Results
description.p:
The table below shows the relative yield of alpha-1-PI and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein in percent of the total amount of the individual proteins loaded onto the column:
FractionAlpha-1-PI (%)Alpha-1-acid-glycoprotein (%)
Run-through/Wash00
Eluate 185< 5
Eluate 21585
The results indicate that the adsorption procedure had separated apha-1-PI (alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor) and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein very efficiently.

SDS-PAGE analysis of alpha-1-PI in Eluate 1 revealed a purity of 80 % and the elastase binding activity was found to be approximately 100 %. Alpha-1-acid-glycoprotein was found to be approximately 45 % pure as determined by SDS-PAGE.

These results further illustrate an effective isolation of alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein using an adsorbent comprising an amino-alkyl ligand under low ionic strength binding conditions.
Isolation of human plasma proteins from human plasma at different pH using an adsorbent coupled with 2-mercaptonicotinic acid.
description.heading: Adsorbent
description.p: The adsorbent was based on agarose with tungsten carbide particles incorporated, the density of the conglomerate particles was 3.6 g/ml and the particle diameter was in the range of 40-100 µm with a volume mean particle diameter of 50 µm. The adsorbent was cross-linked and activated with epichlorohydrin and coupled with 2-mercaptonicotinic acid to obtain a ligand concentration of 32 micromoles per ml sedimented adsorbent.
description.heading: Pre-treatment of the protein solution
description.p:
The protion solution, human plasma, was diluted with demineralised water in a ratio of one volume of plasma to 2 volumes of water. A series of experiments were performed wherein the starting material was adjusted to a range of different pH values (using 1 M hydrochloric acid for titration). The following experiments were performed:
A. pH of protein solution = 3.0
B. pH of protein solution = 4.0
C. pH of protein solution = 4.5
D. pH of protein solution = 5.0
E. pH of protein solution = 5.5
F. pH of protein solution = 6.0
G. pH of protein solution = 6.5
description.heading: Process parameters
description.p: The experiments were performed in a FastLine®10 expanded bed column (Ø=1 cm) product number 7010-0000, UpFront Chromatography A/S.

For each experiment the column was loaded with adsorbent to reach a settled bed height (H0) of 50 cm (corresponding to approx 40 ml settled adsorbent) and washed and equilibrated at 20-25 °C with the following buffers in successive order 1) 1 M NaOH, 2) 40 mM citric acid buffer pH 4.5 3) 40 mM citric acid buffer having the same pH as the protein solution for the specific experiment.
The experiment was performed with a linear flow rate of 400 cm/hr in all steps and the outlet from the column was connected to an UV monitor and recorder.
description.heading: Sample
description.p: 30 ml protein solution (corresponding to 10 ml undiluted plasma) was loaded onto the column.
description.heading: Collection of Fractions:
description.p: Following loading of the protein solution, non-bound and weakly bound material was washed out of the column with 10 mM sodium citrate having the same pH as the sample for that particular experiment. The run-through and washing fraction, RT, (unbound fraction) was collected as one fraction according to the UV monitoring of the column effluent.

Subsequently the bound proteins were eluted in three sequential steps.
Eluate 1 - first elution step was performed with sodium caprylate 5 mg/ml, pH 6.0
Eluate 2 - second elution step was performed with 0.3 M sodium citrate pH 7.4.
Eluate 3 - third elution step was performed with 20 mM sodium citrate + 0.1 M sodium chloride pH 7.4
In between first and second elution step the column was washed with 1 column volume of 1 M sodium citrate pH 7.4

Quantification of human plasma proteins in Run-through/washing fraction and elution 1, 2, and 3: Single Radial Immunodiffusion (SRI) was performed in order to demonstrate the components in each fraction from the column as described in Scand. J. Immunol. Vol. 17, Suppl. 10, 41-56, 1983.

The SRI was performed with the following antibodies, all from Dako Cytomation, Denmark:
AntibodyCode no.µl sample/wellµl per cm2
Rabbit anti human AlbuminA 00015 µl0.30 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human IgGA 04245 µl0.30 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human Alpha-1-PIA 00125 µl0.60 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human FibrinogenA 00805 µl0.40 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human OrosomucoidA 00115 µl0.80 µl per cm2
Rabbit anti human TransferrinA 00615 µl0.30 µl per cm2

A standard curve was established with the protein solution (100 % reference) loaded onto the column in the concentration of 100 %, 80 %, 60%, 40 % and 20 %. Each of the four fractions was determined relative to this standard curve and the relative yield of the specific protein in each protein fraction was determined. If the yield of a specific protein in a specific protein fraction relative to the amount of protein added to the column is above 5 % the protein is defined to distribute into said fraction.

The table illustrates that for the ligand 2-mercaptonicotinic acid, a a pH-value of the protein solution and washing buffer in the range of pH 5.0 to pH 5.5 results in the most effective separation of the proteins analysed. More proteins appear in the non-bound fraction, RT, whenever the pH is below pH 4.5 or above pH 5.5. Below pH 5.0, alpha-1-antitrypsin (alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor) is found to denature (polymerise), which is supported by the finding that it appears in both RT and E2 at and below pH 4.5.

The run-through and washing fraction, RT, (unbound protein fraction) was collected as one protein fraction according to the UV monitoring of the column effluent.

Subsequently the bound proteins were eluted in three sequential steps.

All protein fractions were analysed by NON-REDUCED SDS-PAGE using Invitrogen SDS-Page 4-20 % Tris-Glycine gel (cat no. EC6025). The coomassie stained bands on the SDS PAGE was qualitatively and semi-quantitatively examined by visual inspection to register the distribution of selected plasma proteins in the individual column fractions. If a protein band, present in a specific protein fraction, is estimated to represent more than 10 % of the total protein added to the column the protein is defined as distributing to that particular protein fraction (the threshold value).

description.p: The results illustrate that different un-diluted animal and human plasma behave very similarly when fractionated with a 2-mercapto-nicotinic acid coupled adsorbent under the specified process conditions. The adsorbent bind and elute practically all IgG from all the species tested. The adsorbent bind most of the albumin present in all plasma samples tested and in all experiments the bound albumin is efficiently eluted by the 5 mg/ml sodium caprylate pH 6.0 buffer.

Thus, all adsorbent A-E were designed to deviate from each other only with respect to the size of the particles.

Isolation of human plasma proteins from Cryopoor plasma by using expanded bed adsorption with a flow rate at 450 cm/hr and conditions as under Example 5.

Cryopoor plasma, also called cryosupernatant, produced by slow thawing of frozen human citrate plasma and separating from the cryo-precipitate was used instead of full human citrate plasma in a repetition of example 5. All other parameters were kept constant.
description.heading: Results
description.p: The experiment gave a result similar to the results obtained with full human plasma as described in example 5 except for the substantially complete absence of fibrinogen in protein fraction 4 (eluate 3).
Isolation of Fibrinogen from resolubilised Cryoprecipitate. Batch adsorption using high density adsorbent having low volume mean diameter.
description.heading: Adsorbent
description.p: The adsorbent was based on agarose with tungsten carbide particles incorporated, the density of the conglomerate particles was 3.8 g/ml and the particle diameter was in the range of 20-60 µm with a mean particle diameter of 38 µm. The adsorbent comprised 2-mercaptonicotinic acid as the ligand and a ligand concentration of 31 micromoles per ml sedimented adsorbent.
description.heading: Pre-treatment of protein solution
description.p: Cryoprecipitate produced by slow thawing of 2000 ml frozen human citrate plasma and separated from the cryo-supernatant was re-solubilised by mixing with 10 mM sodium citrate pH 6.7 resulting in approx. 120 ml turbid solution.
description.heading: Batch Adsorption followed by column elution
description.p: The re-solubilised cryo-precipitate was transferred to a 200 ml glass-beaker and 20 ml adsorbent beads thoroughly washed with 10 mM sodium citrate pH 6.7 were added. Mixing of adsorbent and protein solution was performed with a gentle mechanical stirrer for 30 minutes at ambient temperature. Following adsorption the adsorbent was allowed to settle and the supernatant was decanted. Washing buffer (20 mM sodium citrate pH 6.7) was then added as 3 times 100 ml aliquots with mixing, sedimentation and decantation in between each addition. Mixing was performed for 2 minutes for each addition. Following washing, the adsorbent was suspended in a small amount of washing buffer and poured into a 2 cm diameter packed bed column, wherein it settled very quickly. Elution of bound protein was then performed by adding 20 mM potassium phosphate + 0.8 M sodium chloride pH 6.7 at a flow rate of 2 ml per minute. The column elution was monitored with an UV-monitor and the elution peak was collected in one fraction.

The eluate protein fraction was analysed for purity using SDS-PAGE (non-reduced Invitrogen SDS-APGE 4-20 % Tris-glycine gel, cat. no. : EC6025). Fibrinogen functional activity was determined by the von Clauss method (clotting time with bovine thrombin).
description.heading: Results
description.p: Upon stopping the mixing of the adsorbent and the re-solubilised cryoprecipitate after the 30 minutes adsorption period the adsorbent particles sedimented on the bottom of the container within less than 30 seconds. Decantation of supernatants from the settled adsorbent was extremely facile since the adsorbent beads stayed on the bottom of the glass-beaker without any significant tendency to mix with the liquid phase. Addition and washing with 3x washing buffer was equally performed within few minutes due to the fast separation of the adsorbent. The adsorbent was equally packed in the elution column in less than one minute (these procedures normally take up to several hours with low density beads of such a small diameter). The fibrinogen eluted from the column as a highly concentrated clear solution of fibrinogen (elution volume = 21 ml).

SDS-PAGE analysis of the eluted fibrinogen revealed that the protein was more than 85 % pure with IgG being the major contaminant. No albumin could be detected in the eluate. The biological activity of the eluted fibrinogen was found to be fully intact.
The experiment illustrates the significant advantage of using a high density adsorbent having low volume mean diameter for separation of plasma proteins from re-solubilised cryo-precipitate.

Cascade isolation of coagulation/anti-coagulation factors, Albumin, IgG, Fibrinogen, alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor and alpha-1-acid-glycoprotein using three consecutive columns and virus eliminated human plasma as the protein solution.
description.heading: Adsorbents
description.p: The adsorbents used in example 10 (Ligand = 1,4-Diamino-xylylene), example 5 (2-mercapto-nicotinic acid) and example 13 (1,9-diamino-nonane) was utilised in this experiment.
description.heading: Virus elimination
description.p: A human plasma protein solution was treated with a solvent-detergent solution (known as S/D treatment) by the addition of Tri-n-butyl phosphate (0.3 % final concentration) and Tween-80 (1 % final concentration) at 25 degrees Celsius followed by incubation at the same temperature for 6 hours.

The S/D treated plasma was then fractionated in three successive adsorption steps:
Column A: As described in example 10
Column B: As described in example 5
Column C: As described in example 13

Column A was performed as described in example 10. The combined run-through and washing fraction was adjusted to pH 5.0 with 1 M hydrochloric acid and was then diluted with water to obtain a final dilution relative to the volume of starting material corresponding to 1+2 (as described in example 5) and then 120 ml of the diluted protein solution was applied to column B as described in example 5. The combined run-through and washing fraction from column B was collected, pre-treated and processed as described in example 13. For all three columns all elution protein fractions were collected and analysed as described in the respective examples.
description.heading: Results
description.p: The analysis of all column eluates gave essentially the same results as described in the individual examples. Thus, the viral elimination step by S/D treatment did not interfere with the fractionation of the proteins when using the selected adsorbents. At the same time no Tween-80 or Tri-n-butyl phosphate could be detected in any of the isolated protein fractions surprisingly illustrating that none of the adsorbents chosen bind these substances. The isolated protein fractions are therefore efficiently depleted for the viral elimination substances simultaneously with the actual separation of the proteins and no extra steps are therefore required to eliminate these from the isolated proteins.

The experiment further illustrates the successful consecutive separation of human plasma proteins into the following in total 6 different protein fractions having very little cross-contamination and very high yield: A. Coagulation and anti-coagulation factors, B. Albumin, C. IgG and transferrin, D. Fibrinogen, E. Alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor and F. Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein.

Further experimentation with exchanging the order of the adsorption steps have shown that:
Column A must be first in order to avoid inactivation of the coagulation factors at pH 5.0 (used for column B)
Column C must be after column B in order to avoid excessive binding of albumin to column C and consequential serious contamination of alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor.
description.heading: REFERENCES

nplcit.text: Cohn et al, "Separation into Fractions of Protein and Lipoprotein Components" J. Am. Chem. Soc, 68, 459-475, 1946

E. J. Cohn et al., Preparation and Properties of Serum and Plasma Proteins, IV, A System for the Separation into Fractions of the Protein and Lipoprotein Components of Biological Tissues and Fluids, The Journal of the American Chemical Society, vol. LXVIII (Jan.-Jul. 1946), pp. 459-475
Finette G.M.S. et al, Biotechnol. Prog., 1998, 14, pp286-293
Malvern Instruments Ltd (Worcestershire, UK) in their Operators guide (MAN 0320 Issue 1.0 Mar. 2004) to the Mastersizer 2000E

claim.claim-text: Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, das ein Adsorptionsverfahren mit einem ausgedehnten Bett ist.

Verfahren nach einem vorhergehenden Anspruch, wobei nach dem Schritt (e) das Adsorbens mindestens einem zusätzlichen Elutionspuffer unterworfen wird, um mindestens ein zusätzliches Protein, das spezifisch an dem Adsorbens gebunden ist, zu eluieren.
Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 3, wobei die Proteinlösung nicht mit einem Alkohol ergänzt worden ist.
Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei die Proteinlösung mindestens einer Viruseliminationsbehandlung unterworfen wird.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 5, wobei mindestens eine Viruseliminationsbehandlung durchgeführt wird, bevor die Proteinlösung mit dem Adsorbens in Kontakt gebracht wird.

Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 5 bis 6, wobei die Viruseliminationsbehandlung eine Zugabe eines Reinigungsmittels und/oder eines organischen Lösemittels wie etwa Tween, Triton, tri-n-Butylphosphat zu der Proteinlösung mit einbezieht.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei in dem Verfahren das Adsorbens eine funktionalisierte Polymermatrix umfasst, die mehrere kovalent gebundene funktionale Gruppen, die ein aromatisches oder heteroaromatisches Ringsystem und/oder eine oder mehrere Säuregruppen umfassen, trägt.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 8, wobei die funktionale Gruppe aus der Gruppe ausgewählt ist, die aus 2-Mercaptobenzoesäure, 2-Mercaptonicotinsäure, 2-Aminobenzoesäure, 3-Aminobenzoesäure und 4-Aminobenzoesäure, 4-Hydroxyphenyl-mercaptoessigsäure, 4-Hydroxyphenyl-mercaptopropionsäure, 4-Hydroxyphenylmercaptobuttersäure, 2,3-Dihydroxy-benzoesäure, 2,4-Dihydroxy-benzoesäure, 2,5-Dihydroxy-benzoesäure, 2,6-Dihydroxy-benzoesäure, 3,4-Dihydroxy-benzoesäure, 3,5-Dihydroxy-benzoesäure, Mercaptobenzimidazolsulfonsäure, Orthanilsäure, Metanilsäure, Sulfanilsäure, 4-Methylanilin-2-sulfonsäure, 4-Methoxyanilin-2-sulfonsäure, Anilin-2,5-disulfonsäure, N-Methylmetanilsäure, 7-Amino-1-naphthol-3-sulfonsäure, 1-naphthol-4-sulfonsäure, 2-naphthol-6-sulfonsäure und 2-Hydroxy-3-naphthoesäure und 2-Mercaptobenzimidazolsulfonsäure, 3,4-Diaminobenzoesäure und 2-(4-Aminophenylthio)essigsäure besteht.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei die weiteren menschlichen Blutproteine aus der Gruppe ausgewählt sind, die aus IgA, IgM, IgD, IgE, alpha-1-Proteinaseinhibitor, Blut-Prokoagulationsprotein, Blut-Antikoagulationsprotein, thrombolytisches Mittel, antiangiogenes Protein, α-2-Antiplasmin, C-1-Esteraseinhibitor, Apolipoprotein, HDL, LDL, Fibronektin, beta-2-Glycoprotein I, Fibrinogen, Plasminogen, Plasmin, Plasminogenaktivator, Plasminogeninhibitor, Plasmaproteaseinhibitor, Antithrombin III, Streptokinase, inter-alpha-Trypsininhibitor, α-2-Makroglobulin, Amyloidprotein, Ferritin, Präalbumin, GC-Globulin, Heamopexin, C3-Komplement, Transferrin, Urokinase, α-1-Säureglycoprotein und der(die) Koagulations- oder Antikoagulationsfaktor(en) wie etwa Faktor II, Faktor V, Faktor VII, Faktor VIII, von-Willebrand-Faktor, Faktor VIII-von-Willebrand-Faktor-Komplex, Faktor IX, Faktor X, Faktor XI, C1-Inhibitor, Protein C und/oder Protein S besteht.
Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei mindestens zwei Proteinfraktionen durch das Verfahren bereitgestellt werden.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 11, wobei jede der Proteinfraktionen, die in dem Verfahren erhalten wird, ein Ausmaß von Kreuzkontamination von Proteinen von weniger als 20 % aufweist.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei mindestens 2 wie etwa 3, z.B. 4, wie etwa 5, z.B. 6 der Proteine, die aus der Gruppe ausgewählt sind, die aus IgA, IgM, IgD, IgE, alpha-1-Proteinaseinhibitor, Blut-Prokoagulationsprotein, Blut-Antikoagulationsprotein, thrombolytisches Mittel, antiangiogenes Protein, α-2-Antiplasmin, C-1-Esteraseinhibitor, Apolipoprotein, HDL, LDL, Fibronektin, beta-2-Glycoprotein I, Fibrinogen, Plasminogen, Plasmin, Plasminogenaktivator, Plasminogeninhibitor, Plasmaproteaseinhibitor, Antithrombin III, Streptokinase, inter-alpha-Trypsininhibitor, α-2-Makroglobulin, Amyloidprotein, Ferritin, Präalbumin, GC-Globulin, Heamopexin, C3-Komplement, Transferrin, Urokinase, α-1-Säureglycoprotein und der(die) Koagulations- oder Antikoagulationsfaktor(en) wie etwa Faktor II, Faktor V, Faktor VII, Faktor VIII, von-Willebrand-Faktor, Faktor VIII-von-Willebrand-Faktor-Komplex, Faktor IX, Faktor X, Faktor XI, C1-Inhibitor, Protein C und/oder Protein S besteht, gleichzeitig voneinander in mindestens 2 wie etwa 3, z.B. 4, wie etwa 5, z.B. 6 einzelne Proteinfraktionen getrennt werden.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei mindestens 2 wie etwa 3, z.B. 4, wie etwa 5, z.B. 6 von den Proteinen, die aus α-1-Proteinaseinhibitor, Transferrin, Thrombin, Faktor II, Faktor V, Faktor VII, Faktor VIII, Faktor IX, Protein C, Protein S, α-1-Säureglycoprotein und Fibrinogen ausgewählt sind, gleichzeitig voneinander in mindestens 2 wie etwa 3, z.B. 4, wie etwa 5, z.B. 6 einzelne Proteinfraktionen getrennt werden.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei das Fibrinogen an das Adsorbens gebunden ist und gleichzeitig einer oder mehrere der Koagulations- oder Antikoagulationsfaktoren wie etwa Faktor II, Faktor V, Faktor VII, Faktor VIII, von-Willebrand-Faktor, Faktor VIII-von-Willebrand-Faktor-Komplex, Faktor IX, Faktor X, Faktor XI, C1-Inhibitor, Protein C und/oder Protein S als nicht gebundenes Material von dem Adsorbens erhalten werden.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei Albumin und IgG an das Adsorbens gebunden sind und gleichzeitig α-1-Proteinaseinhibitor als nicht gebundenes Material von dem Adsorbens erhalten wird.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei Fibrinogen und IgG an das Adsorbens gebunden sind und gleichzeitig Albumin als nicht gebundenes Material von dem Adsorbens erhalten werden kann.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 17, wobei Fibrinogen und IgG aus dem Adsorbens durch eine stufenweise Elution erhalten werden.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei Fibrinogen, Albumin und IgG an das Adsorbens gebunden sind und gleichzeitig α-1-Proteinaseinhibitor als nicht gebundenes Material von dem Adsorbens erhalten wird.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 19, wobei Fibrinogen, Albumin und IgG aus dem Adsorbens durch eine stufenweise Elution erhalten werden.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei mindestens 1, wie etwa mindestens 2 z.B. 3 von Fibrinogen, Albumin und IgG an das Adsorbens gebunden sind und gleichzeitig α-1-Säureglycoprotein als nicht gebundenes Material von dem Adsorbens erhalten wird.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche, wobei mindestens 1 wie etwa mindestens 2 z.B. 3 von Fibrinogen, Albumin und IgG an das Adsorbens gebunden ist/sind und gleichzeitig α-1-Säureglycoprotein und/oder α-1-Proteinaseinhibitor als nicht gebundenes Material von dem Adsorbens erhalten wird/werden.
Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 14, wobei die nicht gebundene Materialfraktion Albumin umfasst.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1 bis 10, wobei ein oder mehrere Koagulations- oder Antikoagulationsfaktoren, die aus der Gruppe ausgewählt sind, die aus Faktor II, Faktor V, Faktor VII, Faktor VIII, von-Willebrand-Faktor, Faktor VIII-von-Willebrand-Faktor-Komplex, Faktor IX, Faktor X, Faktor XI, C1-Inhibitor, Protein C und Protein S besteht, in einer ersten Iteration des Verfahrens an das Adsorbens gebunden werden.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 24, wobei mindestens ein Protein, das aus der Gruppe ausgewählt ist, die aus Albumin, IgG, Transferrin und Fibrinogen besteht, in einer zweiten Iteration des Verfahrens an das Adsorbens gebunden wird.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 25, wobei mindestens ein Protein, das aus α-1-Proteinaseinhibitor oder α-1-Säureglycoprotein ausgewählt ist, in einer dritten Iteration des Verfahrens an das Adsorbens gebunden wird.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 24, in dem der eine oder die mehreren Koagulations- oder Antikoagulationsfaktoren in getrennten Elutionsschritten aus dem Adsorbens einzeln eluiert werden.
A process according to claim 1, which is an expanded bed adsorption process.

A process according to any preceding claim, wherein, after step (e), the adsorbent is subjected to at least one additional elution buffer to elute at least one additional protein specifically bound to the adsorbent.
A process according to any one of claims 1 to 3, wherein the protein solution has not been supplemented with an alcohol.
A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the protein solution is subjected to at least one virus elimination treatment.
A process according to claim 5, wherein at least one virus elimination treatment is performed prior to contacting the protein solution with the adsorbent.

A process according to any one of claims 5-6, wherein the virus elimination treatment involves addition of detergent and/or an organic solvent, such as tween, triton, tri-n-butylphosphate, to the protein solution.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein in the process the adsorbent comprises a functionalized matrix polymer carrying a plurality of covalently attached functional groups comprising an aromatic or heteroaromatic ring-system and/or one or more acidic groups.

A process according to claim 8, wherein the functional group is selected from the group consisting of 2-mercaptobenzoic acid, 2-mercaptonicotinic acid, 2-aminobenzoic acid, 3-aminobenzoic acid, and 4-aminobenzoic acid, 4-hydroxyphenyl-mercapto-acetic acid, 4-hydroxyphenyl-mercapto-propionic acid, 4-hydroxyphenyl-mercapto-butanoic acid, 2,3-dihydroxy-benzoic acid, 2,4 dihydroxy-benzoic acid, 2,5 di-hydroxy-benzoic acid, 2,6 dihydroxy-benzoic acid, 3,4-dihydroxy-benzoic acid, 3,5-dihydroxy-benzoic acid, mercaptobenzimidazole sulfonic acid, orthanilic acid, metanilic acid, sulphanilic acid, 4-methylaniline-2-sulphonic acid, 4-methoxyaniline-2-sulphonic acid, aniline-2,5-disulphonic acid, N-methylmetanilic acid, 7-amino-1-naphthol-3-sulphonic acid, 1-naphthol-4-sulphonic acid, 2-naphthol-6-sulphonic acid and 2-hydroxy-3-naphthoic acid, and 2-mercaptobenzimidazole-sulphonic acid, 3,4-diaminobenzoic acid, and 2-(4-aminophenylthio) acetic acid.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein further human blood proteins are selected from the group consisting of IgA, IgM, IgD, IgE, alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor, blood pro-coagulation protein, blood anti-coagulation protein, thrombolytic agent, anti-angiogenic protein, α-2-antiplasmin, C-1 esterase inhibitor, apolipoprotein, HDL, LDL, Fibronectin, beta-2-glycoprotein I, fibrinogen, plasminogen, plasmin, plasminogen activator, plasminogen inhibitor, plasma protease inhibitor, anti-thrombin III, streptokinase, inter-alpha-trypsin inhibitor, α-2-macroglobulin, amyloid protein, ferritin, pre-albumin, GC-globulin, haemopexin, C3-complement, transferrin, urokinase, α-1-acid-glycoprotein, and the coagulation or anti-coagulation factor(s) such as Factor II, Factor V, Factor VII, Factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, Factor VIII - von Willebrand factor complex, Factor IX, Factor X, Factor XI, C 1 inhibitor, protein C and/or Protein S.
A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein at least two protein fractions are provided by the process.
A process according to claim 11, wherein each of the protein fractions obtained in the process have an amount of cross-contamination of proteins of less than 20%.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein at least 2, such as 3, e.g. 4, such as 5, e.g. 6 of the proteins selected from the group consisting of IgA, IgM, IgD, IgE, alpha-1-proteinase inhibitor, blood pro-coagulation protein, blood anti-coagulation protein, thrombolytic agent, anti-angiogenic protein, α-2-antiplasmin, C-1 esterase inhibitor, apolipoprotein, HDL, LDL, Fibronectin, bet-2-glycoprotein I, fibrinogen, plasminogen, plasmin, plasminogen activator, plasminogen inhibitor, plasma protease inhibitor, anti-thrombin III, streptokinase, inter-alpha-trypsin inhibitor, α-2-macroglobulin, amyloid protein, ferritin, pre-albumin, GC-globulin, haemopexin, C3-complement, transferrin, urokinase, α-1-acid-glycoprotein, and the coagulation or anti-coagulation factor(s) such as Factor II, Factor V, Factor VII, Factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, Factor VIII - von Willebrand factor complex, Factor IX, Factor X, Factor XI, C1 inhibitor, protein C and/or Protein S are separated simultaneously from each other in at least 2, such as 3, e.g. 4, ,such as 5, e.g. 6 individual protein fractions.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein at least 2, such as 3, e.g. 4, such as 5, e.g. 6 of the proteins selected from α-1 proteinase inhibitor, transferrin, thrombin, Factor II, Factor V, Factor VII, Factor VIII, Factor IX, protein C, Protein S, α-1-acid-glycoprotein and fibrinogen are separated simultaneously from each other in at least 2, such as 3, e.g. 4, such as 5, e.g. 6 individual protein fractions.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein fibrinogen is bound to the adsorbent and simultaneously one or more of the coagulation or anti-coagulation factor(s) such as Factor II, Factor V, Factor VII, Factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, Factor VIII - von Willebrand factor complex, Factor IX, Factor X, Factor XI, C1 inhibitor, protein C and/or Protein S is obtained as non-bound material from the adsorbent.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein albumin and IgG are bound to the adsorbent and simultaneously α-1-proteinase inhibitor is obtained as non-bound material from the adsorbent.
A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein fibrinogen and IgG are bound to the adsorbent and simultaneously albumin may be obtained as non-bound material from the adsorbent.
A process according to claim 17, wherein fibrinogen and IgG are obtained from the adsorbent by stepwise elution.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein fibrinogen, albumin and IgG are bound to the adsorbent and simultaneously α-1-proteinase inhibitor is obtained as non-bound material from the adsorbent.
A process according to claim 19, wherein fibrinogen, albumin and IgG are obtained from the adsorbent by stepwise elution.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein at least 1, such as at least 2 e.g. 3 of fibrinogen, albumin and IgG is/are bound to the adsorbent and simultaneously α-1 acid glycoprotein is obtained as non-bound material from the adsorbent.

A process according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein at least 1, such as at least 2 e.g. 3 of fibrinogen, albumin and IgG is/are bound to the adsorbent and simultaneously α-1-acid glycoprotein and/or α-1-proteinase inhibitor is/are obtained as non-bound material from the adsorbent.
A process according to any one of claims 1-14, wherein the non-bound material fraction comprises albumin.

A process according to claim 1-10, wherein one or more coagulation factors or anti-coagulation factors selected from the group consisting of Factor II, Factor V, Factor VII, Factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, Factor VIII - von Willebrand factor complex, Factor IX, Factor X, Factor XI, C1 inhibitor, protein C and Protein S is bound to the I adsorbent in a first iteration of the process.

A process according to claim 24, wherein at least one protein selected from the group consisting of albumin, IgG, transferrin and fibrinogen is bound to the adsorbent in a second iteration of the process.
A process according to claim 25, wherein at least one protein selected from α-1-proteinase inhibitor or α-1-acid glycoprotein is bound to the adsorbent in a third iteration of the process.
A process according to claim 24 in which the one or more coagulation factors or anti-coagulation factors are eluted from the adsorbent individually in separate elution steps.
Procédé selon la revendication 1, qui est un procédé d'adsorption sur lit élargi.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel, après l'étape (e), l'adsorbant est sujet à au moins un tampon d'élution supplémentaire pour éluer au moins une protéine supplémentaire spécifiquement liée à l'adsorbant.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 3, dans lequel la solution de protéine n'a pas été complétée avec un alcool.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel la solution de protéine est sujette à au moins un traitement d'élimination de virus.
Procédé selon la revendication 5, dans lequel au moins un traitement d'élimination de virus est réalisé avant la mise en contact de la solution de protéine avec l'adsorbant.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 5-6, dans lequel le traitement d'élimination de virus implique l'ajout de détergent et/ou d'un solvant organique, tel que le tween, le triton, la tri-n-butylphosphate, à la solution de protéine.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel l'adsorbant comprend dans le processus un polymère de matrice fonctionnalisé portant une pluralité de groupes fonctionnels attachés de manière covalente comprenant un système de noyau aromatique ou hétéroaromatique et/ou un ou plusieurs groupes acides.

Procédé selon la revendication 8, dans lequel le groupe fonctionnel est sélectionné dans le groupe constitué de l'acide 2-mercaptobenzoïque, l'acide 2-mercaptonicotmique, l'acide 2-aminobenzoïque. L'acide 3-aminobenzoïque, et l'acide 4-aminobenzoïque. L'acide 4-hydroxYPhenyl-mercaDto-acétique, l'acide 4-hydroxyphenvl-mercapto-prot)ionique, l'acide 4-hydroxyPhenyl-mercapto-butanoïque, l'acide 2J-dihvdroxv-beiizoïque, l'acide 2,4-dihydroxy-benzoïque, l'acide 2,5 di-hvdroxv-benzoïque, l'acide 2,6 dihydroxy-benzoïque, l'acide 3,4-dihydroxy-benzoïque, l'acide 3,5-dihydroxy-benzoïque, l'acide mercaptobenzimidazole sulfonique, l'acide orthanilique, l'acide métanilique, l'acide sulfanilique, l'acide 4-methvlaniline-2-sulfonique, l'acide 4-méthoxvaniline-2-sulfonique, l'acide aniline-2,5-disulpbonique, l'acide N-méthvlmétanilique, l'acide 7-amino-1-naphtliol-3-sulfonique, l'acide 1-naphtliol-4-sulphonique, l'acide 2-naphthol-6-sulfonique et l'acide 2-hydroxy-3-naphthoïque et l'acide 2-mercaptobenziinidazole-sulfonique, l'acide 3,4-diaminobenzoïque, et l'acide 2-(4'-aminophénylthio) acétique.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel des protéines de sang humain supplémentaires sont sélectionnées d'un groupe constitué d'albumine IgA, IgM, IgD, IgE, d'inhibiteur de protéinase alpha-1, de protéine pro-coagulation du sang, de protéine anticoagulation du sang, d'agent thrombolytique, de protéine anti-angiogénique, d'α-2-antiplasmine, d'inhibiteur de C-1 estérase, d'apolipoprotéine, d'HDL, de LDL, de fibronectine, de glycoprotéine I bêta-2, de fibrinogène, de plasminogène, de plasmine, d'activateur de plasminogène, d'inhibiteur de plasminogène, d'inhibiteur de protéase de plasma, d'antithrombine III, de streptokinase, d'inhibiteur inter-alpha-trypsine, d'α-2-macroglobuline, de protéine amyloïde, de ferritine, de pré-albumine, de globuline GC, de complément haemopexine C3, de transferrine, d'urokinase, de glycoprotéine acide α-1, et des facteurs de coagulation ou d'anticoagulation tels que le Facteur II, le Facteur V, le Facteur VII, le Facteur VIII, le facteur de von Willebrand, le Facteur VIII - le complexe de facteur de von Willebrand, le Facteur IX, le Facteur X, le Facteur XI, l'inhibiteur C1, la protéine C et/ou la Protéine S.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel au moins deux fractions de protéine sont fournies par le procédé.
Procédé selon la revendication 11, dans lequel chacune des fractions de protéine obtenue dans chaque itération du procédé a une quantité de contamination croisée des protéines inférieure à 20 %.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel au moins 2, 3, par exemple 4, 5, par exemple 6 des protéines sélectionnées dans le groupe constitué d'IgA, d'IgM, d'IgD, d'IgE, d'inhibiteur de protéinase alpha-1, de protéine pro-coagulation de sang, de protéine anticoagulation du sang, d'agent thrombolytique, de protéine anti-angiogénique, d'antiplasmine α-2, d'inhibiteur d'estérase C-1, d'apolipoprotéine, d'HDL, de LDL, de fibronectine, de glycoprotéine I bêta-2 fibrinogène, de plasminogène, de plasmine, d'activateur de plasminogène, d'inhibiteur de plasminogène, d'inhibiteur de protéase de plasma, d'antithrombine III, de streptokinase, d'inhibiteur inter-alpha-trypsine, de macroglobuline α-2, de protéine amyloïde, de ferritine, de pré-albumine, de globuline GC, d'haemopexine, de complément C3, de transferrine, d'urokinase, de glycoprotéine acide α-1, et des facteurs de coagulation ou d'anticoagulation tels que le Facteur II, le Facteur V, le Facteur VII, le Facteur VIII, le facteur de von Willebrand, le Facteur VIII - le complexe de facteur de von Willebrand, le Facteur IX, le Facteur X, le Facteur XI, l'inhibiteur C, la protéine C et/ou la Protéine S sont séparés simultanément l'un de l'autre en au moins 2, 3, par exemple 4, 5, par exemple 6 fractions de protéine individuelles.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel au moins 2, 3, par exemple 4, 5, par exemple 6 des protéines sélectionnées à partir de l'inhibiteur de protéinase α, de la transferrine, de la thrombine, du Facteur II, du Facteur V, du Facteur VII, du Facteur VIII, du Facteur IX, de la protéine C, de la Protéine S, de la glycoprotéine acide α-1 et de la fibrinogène sont séparées simultanément l'une de l'autre en au moins 2, 3, par exemple 4, 5, par exemple 6 fractions de protéine individuelles.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel le fibrinogène est liée à l'adsorbant et simultanément un ou plus des facteur(s) de coagulation ou d'anticoagulation tels que le Facteur II, le Facteur V, le Facteur VII, le Facteur VIII, le facteur de von Willebrand, le Facteur VIII-le complexe de facteur de von Willebrand, le Facteur IX, le Facteur X, le Facteur XI, l'inhibiteur C1, la protéine C et/ou la Protéine S sont obtenus comme matériau non lié à partir de l'adsorbant.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel l'albumine et l'IgG sont liés à l'adsorbant et simultanément l'inhibiteur de protéinase α-1 est obtenu comme matériau non lié à partir de l'adsorbant

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel le fibrinogène et l'IgG sont liés à l'adsorbant et simultanément l'albumine peut être obtenue comme matériau non lié à partir de l'adsorbant.
Procédé selon la revendication 17, dans lequel le fibrinogène et l'IgG sont obtenus à partir de l'adsorbant par élution progressive.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel le fibrinogène, l'albumine et l'IgG sont liés à l'adsorbant et simultanément l'inhibiteur de protéinase α-1 est obtenu comme un matériau non lié à partir de l'adsorbant.
Procédé selon la revendication 19, dans lequel le fibrinogène, l'albumine et l'IgG sont obtenus à partir de l'adsorbant par élution progressive.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel au moins 1, 2, par exemple 3 parmi le fibrinogène, l'albumine et l'IgG est/sont lié(s) à l'adsorbant et simultanément la glycoprotéine acide α-1 est obtenue comme un matériau non lié à partir de l'adsorbant.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel au moins 1, 2, par exemple 3 parmi le fibrinogène, l'albumine et l'IgG est/sont lié(s) à l'adsorbant et simultanément la glycoprotéine acide α-1 et/ou l'inhibiteur de protéinase α-1 est/sont obtenu(s) comme matériau(x) non lié(s) à partir de l'adsorbant.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1-14, dans lequel la fraction de matériau non lié comprend l'albumine.

Procédé selon l'une des revendications 1-10, dans lequel un ou plusieurs facteurs de coagulation ou facteurs d'anticoagulation sélectionnés dans le groupe constitué du Facteur II, du Facteur V, du Facteur VII, du Facteur VIII, du facteur de von Willebrand, du Facteur VIII - du complexe du facteur de von Willebrand, du Facteur IX, du Facteur X, du Facteur XI, d'inhibiteur C1, de la protéine C et de la Protéine S sont liés à l'adsorbant dans la première itération du procédé.

Procédé selon la revendication 24, dans lequel au moins une protéine sélectionnée du groupe constitué d'albumine, d'IgG, de transferrine et de fibrinogène est liée à l'adsorbant dans une seconde itération du procédé.

Procédé selon la revendication 25, dans lequel au moins une protéine sélectionnée à partir de l'inhibiteur de la protéinase α-1 ou de la glycoprotéine acide α-1 est liée à l'adsorbant dans une troisième itération du procédé.

Procédé selon la revendication 24 dans lequel l'unique ou les multiples facteurs de coagulation ou les facteurs d'anticoagulation sont élués individuellement à partir de l'adsorbant lors d'étapes d'élution séparées.
